t: Isaiah 5
The Song of the Vineyard
I*pn will sing for the one I love a*ld song about his vineyard: My*ln loved one had a vineyard on*ld a fertile hillside.

He*ln dug it up and cleared it of stones and*ld planted it with the choicest vines. He*ln built a watchtower in it and*ld cut out a winepress as well. Then*ln he looked for a crop of good grapes, but*ld it yielded only bad fruit.
“Now*pn you dwellers in Jerusalem and people of Judah, judge*ld between me and my vineyard.
What*ln more could have been done for my vineyard than*ld I have done for it? When*ln I looked for good grapes, why*ld did it yield only bad?
Now*ln I will tell you what*ld I am going to do to my vineyard: I*ln will take away its hedge, and*ld it will be destroyed; I*ln will break down its wall, and*ld it will be trampled.
I*ln will make it a wasteland, neither*ld pruned nor cultivated, and*ld briers and thorns will grow there. I*ln will command the clouds not*ld to rain on it.”

The*pn vineyard of the Lord*s Almighty is*ld the nation of Israel, and*ln the people of Judah are*ld the vines he delighted in. And*ln he looked for justice, but saw bloodshed; for*ld righteousness, but heard cries of distress.
Woes and Judgments
Woe*pn to you who add house to house and*ld join field to field till*ln no space is left and*ld you live alone in the land.
The*p Lord*s Almighty has declared in my hearing: “Surely*pn the great houses will become desolate, the*ld fine mansions left without occupants.
A*ln ten-acre vineyard will produce only a bath of wine; a*ld homer of seed will yield only an ephah of grain.”
Woe*pn to those who rise early in the morning to*ld run after their drinks, who*ln stay up late at night till*ld they are inflamed with wine.
They*ln have harps and lyres at their banquets, pipes*ld and timbrels and wine, but*ln they have no regard for the deeds of the Lord,*s no*ld respect for the work of his hands.
Therefore*ln my people will go into exile for*ld lack of understanding; those*ln of high rank will die of hunger and*ld the common people will be parched with thirst.
Therefore*ln Death expands its jaws, opening*ld wide its mouth; into*ln it will descend their nobles and masses with*ld all their brawlers and revelers.
So*ln people will be brought low and*ld everyone humbled, the*ld eyes of the arrogant humbled.
But*ln the Lord*s Almighty will be exalted by his justice, and*ld the holy God will be proved holy by his righteous acts.
Then*ln sheep will graze as in their own pasture; lambs*ld will feed among the ruins of the rich.
Woe*pn to those who draw sin along with cords of deceit, and*ld wickedness as with cart ropes,
to*ln those who say, “Let God hurry; let*ld him hasten his work so*ld we may see it. The*ln plan of the Holy One of Israel— let*ld it approach, let it come into view, so*ld we may know it.”
Woe*pn to those who call evil good and*ld good evil, who*ln put darkness for light and*ld light for darkness, who*ln put bitter for sweet and*ld sweet for bitter.
Woe*pn to those who are wise in their own eyes and*ld clever in their own sight.
Woe*pn to those who are heroes at drinking wine and*ld champions at mixing drinks,
who*ln acquit the guilty for a bribe, but*ld deny justice to the innocent.

Therefore,*ln as tongues of fire lick up straw and*ld as dry grass sinks down in the flames, so*ln their roots will decay and*ld their flowers blow away like dust; for*ln they have rejected the law of the Lord*s Almighty and*ld spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel.

Therefore*ln the Lord’s*s anger burns against his people; his*ld hand is raised and he strikes them down. The*ln mountains shake, and*ld the dead bodies are like refuse in the streets. Yet*pn for all this, his anger is not turned away, his*ld hand is still upraised.
He*pn lifts up a banner for the distant nations, he*ld whistles for those at the ends of the earth. Here*ln they come, swiftly*ld and speedily!
Not*ln one of them grows tired or stumbles, not*ld one slumbers or sleeps; not*ln a belt is loosened at the waist, not*ld a sandal strap is broken.
Their*ln arrows are sharp, all*ld their bows are strung; their*ln horses’ hooves seem like flint, their*ld chariot wheels like a whirlwind.
Their*ln roar is like that of the lion, they*ld roar like young lions; they*ln growl as they seize their prey and*ld carry it off with no one to rescue.
In*ln that day they will roar over it like*ld the roaring of the sea. And*ln if one looks at the land, there*ld is only darkness and distress; even*ld the sun will be darkened by clouds.
